articles.headline: Extravagance Has Its Limits as Belt-Tightening Trickles Up
articles.snippet: In the consumer race to have the latest and the best of everything, the downturn has tripped the reset button.
articles.abstract: In the consumer race to have the latest and the best of everything, the downturn has tripped the reset button.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA  It is a sign of the times when Sacha Taylor, a fixture on the charity circuit in this gala-happy city, digs out a 10-year-old dress to wear to a recent society party.

articles.headline: Drug Investors Lose Patience
articles.snippet: The model of patient biotech investing is being challenged by those who want control of a company’s remains.
articles.abstract: The model of patient biotech investing is being challenged by those who want control of a company’s remains.
articles.lead_paragraph: As merger mania plays out among the pharmaceutical giants, a different sort of financial frenzy has seized some small, struggling drug makers. Investors are demanding that stragglers close up shop and hand over any remaining cash.

articles.headline: Wondering if Crude Could Fall Even More
articles.snippet: Most analysts do not believe prices will continue to fall, but a growing minority says the world recession could push prices still lower.
articles.abstract: Most analysts do not believe prices will continue to fall, but a growing minority says the world recession could push prices still lower.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, as oil traded around $40 a barrel, the conventional wisdom among specialists was that the price decline that began last summer was largely over. Amid production cuts by the OPEC cartel, oil had apparently found a floor that would last until the global economy rebounded.

articles.headline: A Hiring Bind for Foreigners and Banks
articles.snippet: Citing the stimulus package, at least one bank has already rescinded job offers to foreign citizens.
articles.abstract: Citing the stimulus package, at least one bank has already rescinded job offers to foreign citizens.
articles.lead_paragraph: What could be worse than graduating from an American business school this year with an interest in banking?

articles.headline: 2 West Africa Slayings May Signal a New Day
articles.snippet: The president and army chief of staff of Guinea-Bissau died after a rivalry that has destabilized the country.
articles.abstract: The president and army chief of staff of Guinea-Bissau died after a rivalry that has destabilized the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: BISSAU, Guinea-Bissau — Just after sunset, the general got up from under his favorite mango tree. As he climbed toward his second-floor office, a remote-controlled bomb under the staircase exploded, crumpling the building’s flank into a jumble of rubble.

articles.headline: Obama’s Budget Faces Test Among Party Barons
articles.snippet: President Obama will rely on Congressional committee gatekeepers to determine how his tax and spending plans move forward.
articles.abstract: President Obama will rely on Congressional committee gatekeepers to determine how his tax and spending plans move forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  What the Democratic barons of Congress liked best about President Obama’s audacious budget was his invitation to fill in the details. They have started by erasing some of his.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: To Halt Slide, Apply Debt or Control?
articles.snippet: Powerful interests in the United States are expected to oppose European and Japanese pressure for international financial regulation.
articles.abstract: Powerful interests in the United States are expected to oppose European and Japanese pressure for international financial regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When the leaders of 20 nations met in Washington in November to face down a grave economic crisis that imperiled them all, the air was filled with promises of a new era of global regulation intended to match a new era of global risk.

articles.headline: Putting a Bull’s-Eye on a Tax Loophole
articles.snippet: Notables like Robert E. Rubin say so-called carried interest probably should be taxed like regular income.
articles.abstract: Notables like Robert E. Rubin say so-called carried interest probably should be taxed like regular income.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tucked away on Page 122 of President Obama’s budget is a proposal that has the fast money crowd up in arms: “Tax carried interest as ordinary income.”

articles.headline: Is This a Shakespeare Which I See Before Me?
articles.snippet: A group of Shakespeare scholars and art historians say that a recently discovered portrait is the only known likeness to have been painted in his lifetime.
articles.abstract: A group of Shakespeare scholars and art historians say that a recently discovered portrait is the only known likeness to have been painted in his lifetime.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Nearly 400 years after his death, William Shakespeare appeared in a new and more handsome guise on Monday, thanks to a recently discovered portrait that a group of Shakespeare scholars and art historians said was the only known likeness to have been painted in his lifetime.

articles.headline: In a Switch, Citigroup Lifts Stocks
articles.snippet: A glimmer of optimism about the nation’s banks sparked a rally but many experts warned that it could be short-lived.
articles.abstract: A glimmer of optimism about the nation’s banks sparked a rally but many experts warned that it could be short-lived.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hopes that maybe, just maybe, the nation’s beleaguered banks are on the mend swept Wall Street on Tuesday, unleashing a breathtaking stock market rally that left investors a bit giddy but had many experts warning that this rally, like so many before it, could falter as fast as it began.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Jack Healy
